<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Le sourire: Journal méchant, Mar. 1900  
1900  
Composition with a Turkey: only state  
Mimeograph in brownish-black ink, with wood-block print in black ink on cream wove paper; 318 × 505 mm (full sheet); 318 × 253 mm (folded sheet); 265 × 165 mm (image)  
Signed recto, lower left, in pen and black ink: P.G  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Print Sales Miscellaneous Fund, 1947.685  
Guérin 82, Kornfeld 65 B  
For the inside and back, see fig. 117.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin produced nine issues of Le sourire (The Smile), his “serious newspaper,” as well as three supplements; this issue is the eighth and did not contain a supplement. This is also the fourth issue in which Gauguin replaced the word sérieux with méchant (“wicked”) in the title, a term he adopted to underscore its role as a purely satirical journal. Using the new technology of mimeography that he encountered while clerking as a draftsman in Papeete, he created a satirical newspaper for local monthly distribution. The machine that Gauguin used was likely an Edison Mimeograph Model 0. These devices were manufactured in Chicago by the A. B. Dick Company and had only become available in 1897. So popular was the machine, which greatly improved the efficiency of bureaucratic offices, that by the time Gauguin gained access to one in 1899, he described it as “all the rage.” It is likely that this duplicating technology also appealed to the artist on a conceptual level, considering his history of experimentation with various transfer processes.

The format of Le sourire is not immediately intuitive. The unusual orientation of text relative to the folding of the sheets indicates that the journal was intended to be read by turning the pages from left to right. Gauguin hoped to use the mimeograph machine to print images and text simultaneously (see Technical Overview). Unfortunately, the technology had limits that thwarted his aesthetic ambitions; the vignettes sprinkled throughout the text of the August, September, and October 1899 issues were rendered partially illegible due to the broken lines and uneven printing. In this issue of the journal, all of the illustrations were produced as wood-block prints. The artist’s initials are legible in the lower left.

An impression of Composition with a Turkey adorns the front page. An excess of linseed oil is indicated by the migration of the binder in the black printing ink into the paper. This is visible as dark brown discoloration and strike-through on the verso as well as on the sheet facing it. The rest of the issue was printed by applying brownish-black ink through a mimeograph stencil. The stencil itself is responsible for the grainy appearance of the text (see Technical Overview). The mimeograph ink also contained an excess of oil, which has resulted in golden brown haloes and significant strike-through.

The paper that Gauguin selected is only slightly higher quality than newsprint. It is a thin, soft, short-fibered paper with a slight texture that is visible in transmitted light. Because the paper was formatted for use with the mimeograph machine and because Gauguin was notoriously low on money and supplies, it is possible that he procured this paper from the office where he worked and where he returned to do his mimeograph printing. This same paper appears again in Gauguin’s later work, including the transfer drawings Woman with a Cat (cat. 123) and Sister of Charity (cat. 125)

318 × 505 mm (full sheet); 318 × 253 mm (folded sheet); 265 × 165 mm (image)

In 1948, when the issue entered the Art Institute’s collection, there was a thick paper guard adhered along the left edge of the pages that mistakenly identified it as the spine edge of the issue. It also made opening the issue impossible. It was removed, and toned Japanese paper was used to properly reattach the pages along the right edge restoring its original format. Cellophane tapes were removed along the central folds of the title page as well.

The issue is in fair condition.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Gauguin gave his publication the subtitle Journal sérieux for the first four months of its production, but by December of 1899, he changed it to Journal méchant (“wicked newspaper”).

Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

For Gauguin’s work in Papeete, see Bengt Danielsson, Gauguin in the South Seas, trans. Reginald Spink (Doubleday, 1964).

“J’ai créé en outre un journal ‘Le Sourire’ autographié Système Edison, qui fait fureur” (I have also created a newspaper, The Smile, using the Edison printing system, which is all the rage). Gauguin to Monfreid, Dec. 1899, in Lettres de Gauguin à Daniel de Monfreid, ed. Annie Joly-Segalen, introduction by Victor Segalen (G. Falaize, 1950), p. 151, no. 59. Translation by the authors.

For more on Gauguin’s experiments with transfer techniques, see Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44. See also Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973).
